Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone, in terms of maximum sustained winds, on record to impact Australia. The 17th and final storm of the 2005–06 Australian region cyclone season, Monica originated from an area of low pressure off the coast of Papua New Guinea on 16 April 2
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: 16 April 2006... Dissipated: 28 April 2006

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica originated from an area of low pressure that formed early on 16 April 2006 off the coast of Papua New Guinea.
The storm made landfall roughly 40 km (25 mi) south-southeast of the Lockhart River with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph) 10-minute sustained).
Monica made landfall in the Northern Territory, roughly 35 km (22 mi) west of Maningrida, as a Category 5 cyclone with winds of 250 km/h (160 mph) 10-minute sustained).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Linda (2015) was a strong tropical cyclone that resulted in heavy rains across portions of Mexico and the Southwestern United States. The seventeenth named storm, eleventh hurricane, and eighth major hurricane of the season, Linda developed southwest of Mexico from a low-pressure area on September 5 and intensified into Tropical Storm Linda by September 6. The system further strengthened into a hurricane by the next day and reached its peak intensity as a 125 mph (205 km/h) Category 3 major hurricane on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale on September 8. Linda brought rainfall to nine states in Mexico, causing flooding and mudslides, especially in Oaxaca, Sinaloa, and Zacatecas. In the Southwestern United States, moisture from the storm enhanced the local monsoon, bringing above-average rainfall and flash flooding incidents in California and Utah.
Time_with_Annotation: The event started on September 5, 2015, 'Tropical Depression Fifteen-E developed at 18:00 UTC on September 5' (source: formed: September 5, 2015; Tropical Depression Fifteen-E developed at 18:00 UTC on September 5 in the original text). The event ended on September 14, 2015, 'degenerated into a trough while still well west of Baja California on September 14' (source: degenerated into a trough while still well west of Baja California on September 14 in the original text).

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The outer bands of Linda brought rainfall to nine states across Mexico: Baja California, Baja California Sur, Colima, Jalisco, Nayarit, Sinaloa, Sonora and Zacatecas.

Moisture from the hurricane's remnants partially contributed to an enhanced monsoon across the Southwestern United States, combining with a seasonable upper-level trough to bring above-average rainfall to many areas.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: 22 total" (from the article's information box)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "The first storm resulted in a 3.42 ft (1.04 m) rise along the Short Creek, as measured by a stream gauge in Colorado City, Arizona, in 19 minutes around 21:18 UTC (3:18 p.m. MDT), with residents gathering nearby to observe. Between 22:48 and 23:05 UTC (4:48 and 5:05 p.m. MDT), a second surge of water swept down the creek with the Colorado City gauge reporting a rise of 5.36 ft (1.63 m); the gauge stopped reporting at 23:47 UTC (5:47 p.m. MDT). The second flood swept away two vehicles carrying a collective 16 people while they were observing the rising waters. Thirteen people were killed and three children were rescued. Six bodies were recovered in Utah and two in Arizona, 2.5 mi (4.0 km) downstream. Other bodies were found up to 7 mi (11 km) downstream." (from the article's 'Impact and aftermath' section, 'United States', 'Utah' subsection)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Keyhole Canyon at Zion National Park
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Flow along the Virgin River dramatically increased following the rains, with the river's North Fork experiencing a rise from 55 ft3 (1.5 m3) per second to 2,630 ft3 (74.5 m3) per second in just 15 minutes. All seven people were swept away by the ensuing flood and died." (from the article's 'Impact and aftermath' section, 'United States', 'Keyhole Canyon at Zion National Park' subsection)

"A man from Hurricane, Utah, 15 mi (24 km) west of Hildale, died on September 14 after being swept away by floods while traveling remote dirt roads." (from the article's 'Impact and aftermath' section, 'United States', 'Hurricane, Utah' subsection)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Carrie was the strongest tropical cyclone of the 1957 Atlantic hurricane season. The third named storm and second hurricane of the year, Carrie formed from an easterly tropical wave off the western coast of Africa on September 2, a type of tropical cyclogenesis typical of Cape Verde-type hurricanes. Moving to the west, the storm gradually intensified, reaching hurricane strength on September 5. Carrie intensified further, before reaching peak intensity on September 8 as a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 km/h) in the open Atlantic Ocean.
Time_with_Annotation: The system was listed to have reached tropical depression intensity at 0600 UTC that day... The hurricane continued to steadily intensify as it moved westwards... On September 2, a trough was identified along the western coast of Africa... Moving towards the west as a result of a strong Azores High, the disturbance passed over Cape Verde on September 2... The hurricane began to steadily weaken again beginning on September 15... As it curved and accelerated eastward in response to a second trough of low pressure, Carrie maintained hurricane intensity up until September 23, when it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone... The remnant system continued eastwards until it dissipated over Ireland by 1800 UTC on September 28.

Country_with_Annotation.Bermuda: Passing well north of Bermuda on September 16, effects of Carrie on Bermuda were minimal, with peak gusts reaching only 35 mph (56 km/h).
Country_with_Annotation.Azores: As an extratropical storm, Carrie impacted the Azores, though damages, if any, remain unknown.
Country_with_Annotation.British_Isles: As an extratropical storm, Carrie brought strong storm surge and heavy rain to the British Isles, claiming three lives.
Country_with_Annotation.France: The hurricane's long duration and path in open water helped it attain several Atlantic hurricane records.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: As an extratropical storm, Carrie brought strong storm surge and heavy rain to the British Isles, claiming three lives... The German ship Pamir encountered the storm and capsized on September 21, resulting in the deaths of 80 crew members on board.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The German barque Pamir, en route from Buenos Aires to Hamburg, Germany, encountered the hurricane southwest of the Azores on September 21... The ship sank due to the effects of Carrie, and 80 people out of the 86 crew members on board the ship perished.

As an extratropical storm, Carrie impacted the Azores, though damages, if any, remain unknown. The extratropical remnants of Carrie later struck the British Isles on September 24 and 25, causing strong winds, waves, and severe flooding... Winds from the system were estimated at 50 mph (80 km/h). The strong waves caused extensive property damage and killed three.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Due to its distance away from any major land masses, Carrie caused minimal damage along its path.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Cristobal was a moderately strong Atlantic tropical cyclone that affected multiple landmasses from Puerto Rico to Iceland in late August and early September 2014. The storm formed on August 23 near the Caicos Islands from a long-tracked tropical wave and moved generally northward, gradually intensifying despite a ragged appearance on satellite imagery. Cristobal achieved its peak strength as a Category 1 hurricane on August 28, with winds of 85 mph (140 km/h), and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on August 29. The system retained much of its strength as it sped across the northern Atlantic and struck Iceland on September 1.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: August 23, 2014; Extratropical: August 29, 2014; Dissipated: September 2, 2014

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: As Cristobal's parent wave moved over Puerto Rico, it engaged with an abnormally moist air mass to produce torrential rain totaling more than 10 in (250 mm).
La Romana, Dominican Republic, recorded 5.04 in (128 mm) of rain in 24 hours on August 23 and 24, the result being destructive flooding.
In neighboring Haiti, flooding totally destroyed four homes and heavily damaged 28 others, with a total of about 640 families left temporarily homeless.

Shortly after the storm's genesis, tropical storm warnings were issued for the central and southeastern Bahamas and the Turks and Caicos Islands. The advisories were discontinued by August 25. Heavy rain fell over the region, reaching 10.9 in (280 mm) on the island of Providenciales, where one person drowned in the ensuing floods.

A tropical storm watch was issued for Bermuda on August 25, and ultimately discontinued about three days later. Cristobal ultimately passed well to the northwest of the island, producing breezy conditions and heightened surf.
The offshore hurricane lashed the East Coast of the United States with high swells and rip currents, prompting widespread swimming restrictions and bans.
In southern Iceland, the extratropical remnants of Cristobal produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall, leading to extensive flooding in the capital city of Reykjavík.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Paragraph: Before its classification as a tropical cyclone, the disturbance that would become Cristobal dropped heavy rain over Puerto Rico, locally reaching 13.21 in (336 mm). Widespread flooding and scattered landslides affected the territory, with 19 large rivers exceeding minor flood stage. ... The system went on to douse the island of Hispaniola with torrential rain, leading to at least four drowning deaths in Haiti and the Dominican Republic. ... Another person was killed by floodwaters in the Turks and Caicos. ... Later, the extratropical remnants of Cristobal buffeted Iceland with heavy rain and gusty winds, causing flooding around the capital city of Reykjavík.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Paragraph: Before its classification as a tropical cyclone, the disturbance that would become Cristobal dropped heavy rain over Puerto Rico, locally reaching 13.21 in (336 mm). Paragraph: The island of Hispaniola also received damaging rainfall from the slow-moving storm. ... At least two people in the country were swept away by rushing waters, and many others sustained injuries.

Paragraph: The island of Hispaniola also received damaging rainfall from the slow-moving storm. ... Two people were killed in the Dominican Republic, one of them after attempting to drive across a flooded river in the Hato Mayor Province.

Paragraph: Shortly after the storm's genesis, tropical storm warnings were issued for the central and southeastern Bahamas and the Turks and Caicos Islands. ... Floodwaters on North Caicos ran 5 ft (1.5 m) deep, blocking access to some communities. Governor Peter Beckingham reported 'extensive damage to peoples' property and possessions' throughout the overseas territory.

Paragraph: In southern Iceland, the extratropical remnants of Cristobal produced gusty winds and heavy rainfall, leading to extensive flooding in the capital city of Reykjavík. The fire department there responded to 37 calls for flooded buildings.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Earl was a large, long-lived Category 2 hurricane that brought heavy rain to Puerto Rico and Newfoundland in September 2022 despite remaining mostly out to sea. The fifth named storm and second hurricane of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season, Earl originated from a tropical wave that moved off the coast of Africa on August 25. The wave struggled to develop over the next week as it moved west-northwestward in a marginally conducive environment. Eventually, the system was able to organize into Tropical Storm Earl on September 3... Earl eventually reached Category 2 hurricane status, before repeated dry air entrainments caused the storm to fluctuate in intensity... Earl reached peak winds of 110 mph (175 km/h) before quickly becoming extratropical off the coast of Newfoundland on September 10.
Time_with_Annotation: Earl originated from a tropical wave that was producing widespread disorganized showers and thunderstorms when it formed off the coast of Africa on August 25... Earl developed into Tropical Storm Earl early on September 3... Hurricane Hunters data showed it to have developed an eye of almost 60 mi (97 km) and a fairly symmetric wind field... Earl had reached Category 2 strength... Earl had attained peak sustained winds of 105 mph (165 km/h)... Earl briefly weakened down to Category 1 hurricane strength... before transitioning into an extratropical cyclone due south of Cape Race, Newfoundland six hours later... Earl continued to move northeast after becoming extratropical and moved north of the Azores, approaching Europe. Earl continued to spiral north before dissipating on September 15

Country_with_Annotation.Puerto Rico: In Salinas, Puerto Rico, 2 people died after being struck by lightning while riding a jet ski.
Country_with_Annotation.Bermuda: Bermuda was hit with sustained winds of 35 mph (60 km/h) as Hurricane Earl passed within about 90 mi (145 km) away from the island's eastern coast; much higher gusts were reported, including one of 67 mph (108 km/h) at the National Museum of Bermuda.
Country_with_Annotation.Newfoundland: Hurricane-force winds hit Grand Bank. Additionally, the cyclone caused rough surf which damaged the breakwater on the coast near Trepassey, Newfoundland and Labrador, bringing localized flooding to the area.
Country_with_Annotation.British Isles: Despite being far away from the United Kingdom and Ireland, the countries still saw heavy rainfall and rough surf from its outer bands.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Four fatalities were related to Hurricane Earl: two from lightning in Puerto Rico and two from rip currents in New Jersey.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Salinas, Puerto Rico, 2 people died after being struck by lightning while riding a jet ski.
Two people drowned off the coast of New Jersey due to rip currents: one in Ocean City and the other in Loveladies.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: overall damage from the storm was minor.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A deadly storm (Klaus) blew in off the Atlantic and made its way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead (at the latest count). Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France.
Time_with_Annotation: windstorm Klaus hit France on 24th January 2009

Country_with_Annotation.France: Windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land in France according to Meteo France.
Country_with_Annotation.Spain: Windstorm Klaus blew in off the Atlantic and made it’s way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Windstorm Klaus blew in off the Atlantic and made it’s way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead (at the latest count).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Windstorm Klaus blew in off the Atlantic and made it’s way across southern France and northern Spain on Saturday, causing widespread damage and leaving 20 people dead (at the latest count).

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Winds from the storm broke records for France with the strongest recorded gust hitting 184kph according to Meteo France. No estimates for damage totals have been released by either the French or Spanish governments but it looks likely that this could top the 1999 winter storm Martin as windstorm Klaus has affected a wider area of land.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Floyd was a very powerful Cape Verde hurricane which struck the Bahamas and the East Coast of the United States. It was the sixth named storm, fourth hurricane, and third major hurricane in the 1999 Atlantic hurricane season... Floyd triggered the fourth largest evacuation in US history... The hurricane formed off the coast of Africa and lasted from September 7 to 19, becoming extratropical after September 17, and peaked in strength as a very strong Category 4 hurricane... It was among the largest Atlantic hurricanes of its strength ever recorded, in terms of gale-force diameter.
Country_Merge: East Coast of the United States

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Hurricane Floyd lashed the Bahamas with winds of 155 mph (249 km/h) and waves up to 50 ft (15 m) in height.
Farther north in Georgia, Floyd produced wind gusts of 53 mph (85 km/h) at Savannah International Airport.
Tropical storm force winds affected the entirety of the South Carolina coastline, with statewide damage estimated at $17 million.
North Carolina received the brunt of the storm's destruction. In all, Hurricane Floyd caused 51 fatalities in North Carolina, much of them from freshwater flooding, as well as billions in damage.
Hurricane Floyd left $101 million in damage in Virginia, and contributed to four fatalities.
As Floyd moved northward from Virginia, a stalled cold front acted as a conveyor belt of tropical moisture across the Mid-Atlantic.
The hurricane's rainbands moved across Maryland, dropping 12.59 in (320 mm) of rainfall in Chestertown, Maryland.
Hurricane Floyd left $8.42 million in damage in Delaware, and the storm dropped torrential rainfall, reaching 12.58 in (320 mm) in Greenwood, Delaware.
As Floyd continued up the coast, it dropped heavy rainfall in New Jersey, reaching 14.13 in (359 mm) in Little Falls.
Floyd killed 13 people, largely due to drownings, fallen trees, or heart attacks, and another 40 people were severely injured.
Floyd's rainfall resulted in flooding that killed two people in the state, and caused several creeks and rivers to exceed their banks.
One person drowned in the state due to the swollen Quinnipiac River.
Floyd's effects in Rhode Island were limited to rainfall and winds, which brought down trees and power lines.
Wind gusts in Massachusetts reached 76 mph (122 km/h) at the New Bedford Hurricane Barrier.
Floyd's winds caused power outages for about 10,000 people, while heavy rains rose the banks of rivers.
A tree fell onto a mobile home, killing its occupant.
About 15,000 residents were affected by power outages in Maine.
The remnants of Floyd produced rainfall and gusty winds from Ontario to Atlantic Canada, with 118 km/h (73 mph) occurring along the Saint Lawrence River in Quebec.
Heavy rainfall backed up storm drains in Fredericton, New Brunswick.
About 6,000 people lost power in Nova Scotia.
The Confederation Bridge connecting Prince Edward Island to the mainland shut down during the storm due to 72 miles per hour (116 km/h) winds.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: With a death toll of 85, Hurricane Floyd was the deadliest United States hurricane since Hurricane Agnes in 1972.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Long Hollow Fire was a wildfire burning five miles south of Dufur, Oregon in the United States. The fire was first reported on July 26, 2018 and has burned 78,425 acres (317 km2) . The fire was started by farm equipment.
Time_with_Annotation: The Long Hollow Fire was first reported on July 26, 2018, at 4:45 pm
On July 28, crews focused on targeting the fire in Jones Canyon.
By July 29, the fire had burned over 30,000 acres (121 km2).
As of July 31, the Long Hollow Fire had burned 33,451 acres (135 km2) and was 95 percent contained.
It is the third major fire of the 2018 Oregon wildfire season.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: The Long Hollow Fire was a wildfire burning five miles south of Dufur, Oregon in the United States. The fire was first reported on July 26, 2018 and has burned 78,425 acres (317 km2) .The fire was started by farm equipment. The fire is located just south of the Substation Fire. It is the third major fire of the 2018 Oregon wildfire season.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: No information about deaths was mentioned in the article.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article does not provide specific information regarding the total economic loss or damage caused by the Long Hollow Fire.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A cluster of thunderstorms began to circulate into a tropical disturbance early on August 18. Its circulation became exposed and intensified again later that day. It became Tropical Depression 11W on the evening of August 19 at 1200 UTC (2100 JST) 245 nautical miles (455 kilometers) southeast of Iwo Jima. The storm intensified rapidly in two days to a Category 4 Super Typhoon but weakened as it approached Japan. Mawar made landfall on Honshū as a Category 2 Typhoon on August 25 at 1800 UTC (August 26 0300 JST) with winds of 95 mph (153 km/h). After moving inland to the northwest it was downgraded to a Category 1 typhoon before entering the Pacific Ocean. It was downgraded to a Tropical Storm on August 26 and became extratropical on August 27. The extratropical remnants of Mawar dissipated on August 30.
Time_with_Annotation: A cluster of thunderstorms began to circulate into a tropical disturbance early on August 18. Its circulation became exposed and intensified again later that day. It became Tropical Depression 11W on the evening of August 19 at 1200 UTC (2100 JST) 245 nautical miles (455 kilometers) southeast of Iwo Jima... The extratropical remnants of Mawar dissipated on August 30.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2010-2011 China drought was a drought that began in late 2010 and impacted eight provinces in the northern part of the People's Republic of China (PRC). It was the worst drought to hit the country in 60 years, and it affected most of wheat-producing regions in the PRC. The drought began as early as September 2010 in some regions, though widespread lack of rain and snow began in October. The lack of precipitation caused lower than normal snow cover, putting wheat crops at risk of being killed by frost as well as reducing the amount of moisture in the ground. The provinces of Anhui, Gansu, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu, Shaanxi, Shandong, and Shanxi were impacted by the drought. As well as destroying wheat crops, the drought caused water shortages for an estimated 2.31 million people and 2.57 million livestock. Within the eight provinces, 20% of the farmland and 35% of the entire wheat crop was impacted. By February 2011, the drought hit a total of up to 7,730,000 hectares (19,100,000 acres) of winter wheat that had already been planted. Some lakes, including Lake Hong in Hubei province, dried up significantly, with the Hubei lake shrinking to one-eighth of its normal surface area and one-fifth its usual depth, forcing 3,234 local residents to relocate.
Time_with_Annotation: The drought began as early as September 2010 in some regions,[1]

By the start of June, the drought had affected 35 million people, including 4.2 million facing a drinking water shortage. Direct economic damage had reached 15 billion yuan (about 2.3 billion USD), while several provinces resorted to using cloud seeding to induce artificial rain.[5]

On 24 June, 3.65 million people and 3.47 million heads of livestock were short of drinking water in the autonomous regions of Inner Mongolia and Ningxia and the provinces of Gansu and Shanxi despite the flooding in other parts of China.[6]

Despite flooding in many regions by 20 June 2011, a government minister reported that drought was still affecting 72.19 million mu (4.81 million hectares) in unflooded parts of Hubei, Anhui, and Jiangsu provinces and some northern provinces.[8]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane How was the only tropical cyclone to make landfall on the United States in 1951. It was the eighth storm of the season, forming on September 28 in the northwest Caribbean and, after entering the Gulf of Mexico, turned eastward and became a tropical storm. The storm brought heavy rainfall to Florida, causing flooding and $2 million in damage. Tropical Storm How later became a hurricane, passing near the Outer Banks of North Carolina where it produced strong winds and high tides.
Time_with_Annotation: The origins of Hurricane How were from an easterly wave that organized into a tropical depression, in the western Caribbean Sea on September 28, 1951. It became an extratropical storm on October 7, and the next day the remnants of How dissipated in the far northern Atlantic.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: It moved to the north-northwest, passing by the Yucatan peninsula before turning to the east in the central Gulf of Mexico on October 1... That day, a reconnaissance aircraft in the system reported gale-force winds and, as a result, it was upgraded to Tropical Storm How. The storm strengthened to just below hurricane force, making landfall near Punta Gorda, Florida with 70 mph (110 km/h) winds (115 km/h)... While it crossed the state, the center was not very organized, and consequently the strongest winds were in the south and southeastern portion of the storm; heavy rains, however, fell across its path.

Tropical Storm How emerged into the Atlantic Ocean near Vero Beach, quickly intensifying to hurricane strength by October 3... Turning northeastward, Hurricane How reached peak winds of 100 mph (160 km/h) on October 4 as it passed near the Outer Banks of North Carolina... Subsequently, the hurricane embarked on a slow weakening trend, as it briefly posed a threat to New England. It passed southeast of Cape Cod before turning more to the east-northeast.
Hurricane How produced 50 mph (80 km/h) winds and high tides along the Outer Banks and southeastern Virginia.

In New England, the Weather Bureau issued storm warnings from Block Island, Rhode Island to Portland, Maine, with rains, fog, and heavy surf reported... Several roads were closed in Massachusetts due to the tides.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Offshore, a ship called Southern Isle was wrecked by the high surf. It had been sailing from Puerto Rico with a full load of iron ore and, as it approached the hurricane, the vessel changed directions and slowed. By October 5, winds were strong and the seas were moderately rough. Very quickly, the ship broke into two, which prevented any time to escape on lifeboats. By the day after the wreck, rescue boats and helicopters found seven people, one of whom later died from their injuries. Ultimately, 17 people died in the event.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Overall, Hurricane How caused about $2 million (USD) in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest which burned 150,696 acres (609.8 km2) in July and August 2002, and the largest wildfire of the 2002 California wildfire season... The blaze was started due to the 'careless use of fire'... and spread east through the canyon and threatened the communities of Johnsondale and Ponderosa. It burned within one mile (1.6 km) of the Packsaddle Grove of giant sequoias.
Time_with_Annotation: The McNally Fire burned from July 21 to August 29, 2002, through the Sequoia and Inyo National Forest, as well as 5% of Giant Sequoia National Monument.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest which burned 150,696 acres (609.8 km2) in July and August 2002, and the largest wildfire of the 2002 California wildfire season... The blaze was started due to the 'careless use of fire' near the Roads End Resort in Kern Canyon, and spread east through the canyon and threatened the communities of Johnsondale and Ponderosa.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: An extremely severe drought occurred in the later year of 1991, which intensified in 1994 and 1995 to become the worst on record in Queensland. This drought was influenced by a strong El Niño weather pattern and associated with high temperatures in July and August 1995. So few wheat and barley crops survived, about half the usual for that year, that grains had to be imported from other states. In June 1994, more than ten towns had lost irrigation systems; and some areas had gone five years without decent rainfall. By October 1994, the Condamine River was exhausted, reverting to a series of ponds. Across the state, in more than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, was drought declared.
Time_with_Annotation: A severe drought, referred to as the '90s Queensland Drought, occurred in the later year of 1991, which intensified in 1994 and 1995 to become the worst on record in Queensland. This drought was influenced by a strong El Niño weather pattern and associated with high temperatures in July and August 1995.

Country_with_Annotation.Queensland: the worst on record in Queensland. So few wheat and barley crops survived, about half the usual for that year, that grains had to be imported from other states. Across the state, in more than 13,000 properties, totaling 40% of Queensland, was drought declared.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The drought led to a major loss of production for cotton farms near Moree and Narrabri, and more than ten towns had lost irrigation systems.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Agnes was the costliest hurricane to hit the United States at the time, causing an estimated $2.1 billion in damage. The hurricane's death toll was 128. Agnes was the second tropical cyclone and first named storm of the 1972 Atlantic hurricane season. It developed as a tropical depression on June 14, 1972, from the interaction of a polar front and an upper trough over the Yucatán Peninsula. The storm emerged into the western Caribbean Sea on June 15, and strengthened into Tropical Storm Agnes the next day. Agnes intensified into a hurricane on June 18 while in the southeastern Gulf of Mexico. The hurricane eventually made landfall near Panama City, Florida, late on June 19. After moving inland, Agnes rapidly weakened and was only a tropical depression when it entered Georgia. The weakening trend halted as the storm crossed over Georgia and into South Carolina. While over eastern North Carolina, Agnes re-strengthened into a tropical storm on June 21, as a result of baroclinic activity. Early the following day, the storm emerged into the Atlantic Ocean before re-curving northwestward and making landfall near New York City as a strong tropical storm. Agnes quickly became an extratropical cyclone on June 23.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The hurricane's death toll was 128. The effects of Agnes were widespread, from the Caribbean to Canada, with much of the east coast of the United States affected. Damage was heaviest in Pennsylvania, where Agnes was the state's wettest tropical cyclone. Due to the significant effects, the name Agnes was retired in the spring of 1973.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Ignacio was the latest-forming first hurricane of a Pacific hurricane season since reliable satellite observation began in 1966. The ninth tropical storm of the 2003 Pacific hurricane season, Ignacio developed out of a tropical wave on August 22 a short distance off the coast of Mexico... Hurricane Ignacio continued to quickly intensify after becoming a hurricane, and reached peak winds of 105 mph (169 km/h) later on August 24 while located within 30 miles (48 km)/h) off the coast of Baja California Sur... Hurricane Ignacio was responsible for approximately US$21.2 million of damage.
Time_with_Annotation: Hurricane Ignacio (2003) was formed on August 22, 2003 - 'Developed out of a tropical wave on August 22'... and dissipated on August 27, 2003 - 'Dissipated on August 27 in the central Baja California peninsula'.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Magda was a relatively small tropical cyclone that brought minor damage to parts of Western Australia in January 2010. The storm originated from a tropical low near the Indonesian island of Roti on 18 January and attained tropical cyclone status on 20 January. Magda later reached severe tropical cyclone intensity on 21 January as it approached Western Australia and made landfall in the Kimberley region with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph) before quickly weakening over land. The remnants of Magda persisted until 24 January, at which time they dissipated east of Port Hedland.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: 18 January 2010; Dissipated: 24 January 2010

Country_with_Annotation.Western Australia: The third named storm of the 2009–10 Australian region cyclone season, Magda originated from a tropical low near the Indonesian island of Roti on 18 January... Late on 21 January, Magda made landfall in the Kimberley region with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph) before quickly weakening over land... Following its usage, the name Magda was retired and replaced with Megan... The most severe damage was defoliation around Kuri Bay... Prior to Cyclone Magda's arrival, several severe weather warnings were issued for the coastline of Western Australia... Although the storm made landfall with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph), damage was limited due to the sparsely populated region it struck... Rainfall peaked at 185 mm (7.3 in) in Kuri Bay over a three-day span... Near where the storm made landfall, wind gusts were estimated up to 185 km/h (115 mph), resulting in significant defoliation and affecting a few structures.

Following its usage, the name Magda was retired and replaced with Megan, which was first used in the 2023-24 season.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Helene was a long-lived tropical cyclone that oscillated for ten days between a tropical wave and a 70 mph (110 km/h) tropical storm. It was the twelfth tropical cyclone and eighth tropical storm of the 2000 Atlantic hurricane season, forming on September 15 east of the Windward Islands... The storm was small with an asymmetric wind field, and wind shear displaced the circulation from the deep convection... Upon becoming a tropical storm, Helene gradually turned to the north while rounding an anticyclone to its east... It reached its peak intensity of 70 mph (110 km/h) late on September 21... The storm began weakening on September 22 as it approached the northern Gulf Coast... By 0900 UTC that day, strong wind shear moved the convection away from the center and toward the north and northeast. This prompted NHC forecaster Lixion Avila to remark, 'If I did not have a reconnaissance plane in the area, I would not know there was a tropical cyclone by just observing IR satellite imagery.'... The storm made landfall near Fort Walton Beach, Florida at 1200 UTC on September 22 after weakening from its peak intensity to winds of 40 mph (64 km/h)... Despite strong wind shear, convection increased over Helene's center as the storm moved through North Carolina... Satellite imagery and buoy data indicated that Helene re-intensified into a tropical storm inland over North Carolina... The storm became compact over the northern Atlantic Ocean, with a diameter of 140 mi (230 km)... Strong convection developed over the center on September 24, and the following day Helene re-attained its peak intensity of 70 mph (110 km/h) while southeast of Nova Scotia... The wind estimate was based on observations from the Neptune Olivine, a nearby ship that recorded 64 mph (103 km/h) winds and a barometric pressure of 988 mbar (29.2 inHg); because the ship was located to the south of the center, the storm's minimum pressure was estimated at 986 mbar (29.1 inHg)... Late on September 25, Helene dissipated as it was absorbed by a cold front.
Time_with_Annotation: A tropical wave moved off the African coast on September 10... Tropical Depression Twelve formed on September 15... It was absorbed by a cold front on September 25.

Countries_Affected.Country_with_Annotation: When Tropical Depression Twelve first formed, several governments across the Lesser Antilles issued a tropical storm watch, including the SSS islands, Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, Montserrat, and Saint Kitts and Nevis.

The system also produced heavy rainfall, reaching 6 to 12 in (150 to 300 mm) of rainfall, which resulted in flash flooding and mudslides. One house was destroyed and more than 100 houses were affected in Ponce, forcing several families to evacuate.

As a tropical wave, Helene moved through the Lesser Antilles with strong winds; gusts on Guadeloupe reached 55 mph (89 km/h). The system also produced heavy rainfall, reaching 3.14 in (80 mm) on Antigua. The wave passed to the south of Puerto Rico on September 17 and 18. After the system redeveloped into a tropical depression, the government of Cuba issued a tropical storm warning for the provinces of Isla de la Juventud, Havana, and Pinar del Río, as well as for the city of Havana.

In Alabama, wind gusts reached 36 mph (58 km/h) at Brookley Air Force Base in Mobile; the same station recorded the highest rainfall in the state, with a total of 1.08 in (27 mm). The storm also caused minor beach erosion and coastal damage along Dauphin Island.

Despite being a weak tropical cyclone at landfall, Tropical Storm Helene caused $16 million in damage (2000 USD). In Florida, the storm dropped heavy rainfall along the panhandle, peaking at 9.56 in (243 mm) in Apalachicola. The rains caused flooding, notably in Franklin, Wakulla, and Leon counties, all of which closed schools and public buildings. Flood warnings were issued for areas affected by Tropical Storm Gordon five days prior. High rainfall caused the Sopchoppy River to exceed its banks and reach a record crest of 34.9 ft (10.6 m), breaking the previous record set in 1970. Several homes and nearby roads were flooded near the river. About 100 homes were flooded in Leon County, and 70 streets were flooded in Tallahassee. Portions of U.S. Highway 98 were flooded in Port St. Joe and near Carrabelle. About 70 people had to evacuate their homes due to the flooding. Sustained winds across the state peaked at 30 mph (48 km/h), though gusts reached 45 mph (72 km/h) at Cape San Blas. The winds combined with the heavy rainfall caused trees to fall onto power lines, leaving about 5,000 people without electricity. The storm spawned 6 tornadoes along the panhandle, one of which destroyed several mobile homes in Wakulla. As the storm moved ashore, tides were less than 2 ft (0.61 m) above normal, but were high enough to cause minor beach erosion. In Leon County, the storm destroyed two homes and six mobile homes, and damaged more than 120 homes in Wakulla County.

When Helene moved through Georgia, it had sustained winds of around 30 mph (48 km/h), with higher gusts. It dropped heavy rainfall along its path, with a statewide peak of 5.13 in (130 mm) in Dunwoody. The rainfall alleviated persistent drought conditions across the state. However, the combination of winds and rainfall downed trees and power lines; one falling tree damaged a car in Sandersville.

As Helene moved through South Carolina, it spawned an F2 tornado in Martin that killed one person, injured six, and damaged 12 houses. The highest rainfall in the United States associated with Helene was a total of 9.60 in (244 mm) in Bamberg, though weather radar images estimated totals of up to 14 in (360 mm). The rains caused flooding along Highway 47, in nearby Orangeburg County where 5.3 in (130 mm) were recorded.

Rainfall from the storm extended through Virginia and into Delaware. Off the shore of North Carolina, a station at Diamond Shoal Light reported wind gusts of 70 mph (110 km/h) while Helene was re-intensifying into a tropical storm. Along the coast, the highest gusts were 52 mph (84 km/h), reported at both Cape Lookout and Duck. Rainfall in North Carolina peaked at 8.31 in (211 mm) in Longwood; in Jacksonville, the precipitation caused street flooding.

After re-intensifying into a tropical storm for a second time, Helene passed to the southeast of Atlantic Canada. Although its strongest winds remained offshore, the outer rainbands dropped light precipitation, peaking at 0.89 in (22.5 mm) in eastern Nova Scotia, and 1.18 in (30 mm) in southeastern Newfoundland.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In South Carolina, Helene spawned a tornado that killed one person and injured six others.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Elsa was a tropical storm that formed over the central tropical Atlantic, about 1,150 mi (1,850 km) east-southeast of Barbados. It originated from a tropical wave that moved off the west coast of Africa on June 27 and became organized as a tropical depression on June 30, strengthening to a tropical storm soon thereafter. Elsa then became a hurricane around 12:00 UTC on July 2, as its center moved just south of Barbados, and reached its peak intensity six hours later with maximum 1-minute sustained winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 991 mbar (29.3 inHg). The storm then weakened back into a tropical storm and made landfall in Cuba on July 5, before emerging into the Gulf of Mexico early on the next day. Elsa paralleled the west coast of Florida and made landfall again in Taylor County, Florida, on July 7, with maximum winds of about 65 mph (100 km/h). The storm then accelerated northeastward across the southeast and Mid-Atlantic states, restrengthening slightly due to its proximity to the Atlantic. Elsa emerged back over water off New Jersey early on July 9 and moved over eastern Long Island and western Rhode Island, before becoming extratropical at 18:00 UTC that day, while moving through New England.
Country_Merge: East Coast of the United States
Countries_Affected: East Coast of the United States

Country_with_Annotation.Lesser_Antilles: Hurricane Elsa caused extensive damage on several islands in the Lesser Antilles, including Barbados, where it brought down trees, damaged roofs, caused widespread power outages, and caused flash flooding.
Country_with_Annotation.Greater_Antilles: Elsa made landfall in Cuba, causing flash flooding and mudslides, and also affected the Dominican Republic, Haiti, and Jamaica, where it caused floods, impassable roads, and power outages.
Country_with_Annotation.Venezuela: The text does not provide specific details about the impact of Hurricane Elsa on Venezuela, but it is mentioned as one of the affected areas.
Country_with_Annotation.Colombia: The text mentions that Colombian authorities issued a warning of heavy rainfall and waves of up to three meters on the Caribbean coasts of the country before Elsa headed to the Dominican Republic and Haiti.
Country_with_Annotation.East_Coast_of_the_United_States: Hurricane Elsa caused widespread impacts throughout the Eastern United States, including spawning 18 tornadoes and causing at least $775 million in damages. In Florida, the storm produced a 2-3 ft storm surge, caused downed trees and power outages, and resulted in one death.
Country_with_Annotation.Atlantic_Canada: Post-tropical Elsa caused many outages and high amounts of rainfall in Atlantic Canada.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Altogether there were 13 deaths associated with Elsa: nine in the Florida Straits, two in the Dominican Republic, one in Martinique, and one in the United States. As Elsa raced past the Lesser Antilles, it caused extensive damage on several islands. In Barbados, the storm brought down trees, damaged roofs, caused widespread power outages, and caused flash flooding. Its main impact in Cuba was flash flooding and mudslides. The storm caused widespread damage throughout the U.S., especially in the Northeast. Atlantic Canada experienced many outages and high amounts of rainfall from a post-tropical Elsa.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: More than 1,300 homes were damaged, including 62 homes which were completely destroyed on the island. The entirety of the island lost electricity as Elsa passed to the south, with 24 electricity poles being knocked down and 74 reports of trees being uprooted.
Strong winds caused by Elsa toppled walls in houses in southwestern Baoruco Province, resulting in two separate fatalities of a 15-year-old boy and 75-year-old woman on July 3.

Damage was relatively limited while Elsa passed close to the Tiburon Peninsula, although there was reported damage to banana and maize crops and to roofs of some structures; there were no other forms of reported significant damage to infrastructure.

Flash flooding caused by Elsa led to roads being impassable across Saint Catherine and Portmore. Several communities in Kingston, Saint Andrew, Saint Thomas, Saint Catherine, and Clarendon were also flooded. A gully in Clarendon overflowed, causing residents nearby to be stuck in their homes. Several flights at the Sangster International Airport were suspended throughout July 4-5, due to rough weather conditions.
A person was killed in Jacksonville when a tree fell and struck two cars. The person was a 26-year-old male Navy Sailor, named Deshawn Levon Johnson.

An EF1 tornado struck St. Marys, ripping an exterior wall off of a house before moving through an RV park at Naval Submarine Base Kings Bay. It flipped multiple RVs, including two that were flipped upside down, while throwing another into a nearby lake along with a pickup truck. There were 17 people that were injured, including a pregnant woman.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm dealt upwards of $1.2 billion in damages in the United States, with additional damage in the Caribbean.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Based on the provided article, the main event is the formation and progression of Hurricane Danielle. The event started as an area of low pressure over the central subtropical Atlantic on September 1, which developed into Tropical Depression Five and further strengthened into Tropical Storm Danielle by 12:00 UTC. Danielle became a hurricane around 24 hours later and reached its peak intensity with sustained winds of 85 mph (140 km/h) on September 5. The hurricane eventually weakened and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on September 8, which later brought heavy rain to Portugal and Spain.
Time_with_Annotation: On August 31, an area of low pressure formed along a decaying frontal zone over the central subtropical Atlantic. The disturbance quickly developed into Tropical Depression Five early on September 1 roughly 715 mi (1,150 km) southeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland, before strengthening into Tropical Storm Danielle by 12:00 UTC.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: An area of low pressure formed along a decaying frontal zone over the central subtropical Atlantic. The disturbance quickly developed into Tropical Depression Five early on September 1 roughly 715 mi (1,150 km) southeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland.

The remnants of Danielle dissipated offshore Portugal as an extratropical cyclone, bringing heavy rain to the country, including 3.3 in (84 mm) of precipitation in Guarda in 24 hours. Between September 12–13, 644 accidents were reported throughout the country, along with many instances of downed trees and flash floods. One man was hospitalized after he was swept away by floodwaters. Much of Spain was put on yellow alert as wind, rain and thunderstorms triggered by the cyclone moved inland. Floods and landslides caused major damage and at least four vehicles were dragged into the Zêzere River in Manteigas.
Much of Spain was put on yellow alert as wind, rain and thunderstorms triggered by the cyclone moved inland.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Storm Ampil, known in the Philippines as Severe Tropical Storm Inday, was a tropical cyclone that caused moderate damage in the Ryukyu Islands and East and Northeast China in late July 2018. The tenth named storm of the annual typhoon season, Ampil developed into a tropical depression east of Luzon on July 17 and became a severe tropical storm late on July 19 as it moved northwest. The system passed over Okinawa Island from July 20 to 21 and made landfall in Shanghai, China, on July 22. Ampil weakened slowly over land and degraded to a tropical depression on July 23 before dissipating fully a day later over the Russian Far East.
Time_with_Annotation: The system consolidated into a tropical depression at 12:00 UTC on July 17... Ampil made landfall over eastern Chongming Island in Shanghai, becoming only the third tropical cyclone to make landfall in Shanghai since 1949 around 04:30 UTC, July 22... the leftover system eventually dissipated over the Russian Far East while still inland by 12:00 UTC on July 26.

Country_with_Annotation.Japan: On July 20, the JMA issued a storm warning (Japanese: 暴風警報) for Okinawa Island... Adverse weather conditions caused 106 flights and 112 sailings to be canceled from July 20 to 21... The Okinawa Urban Monorail suspended operations for the morning of July 21... The Okinawa Prefectural Museum and the Urasoe Art Museum closed for the morning on July 21... Major department stores across Okinawa were closed till about noon on July 21.
Country_with_Annotation.China: Ahead of Ampil on July 20, the Chinese National Meteorological Center issued a yellow alert, the third-highest rating on their warning system... A total of 387,100 people across Shanghai, Jiangsu, and Zhejiang were evacuated... More than 600 flights at Shanghai's Pudong and Hongqiao airports were canceled... Ferry lines across the Yangtze River suspended operations... When Ampil made landfall in eastern Chongming District on July 22, it became the only third tropical cyclone to make landfall over Shanghai since 1949... As Ampil tracked further inland from July 22 to 25, it produced a large swath of heavy rain across East and Northeast China... Throughout the country, Ampil affected 2.334 million people, killing one person in Shandong with a fallen tree and causing direct economic losses of ¥1.63 billion (US$246 million).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: About 387,000 people were evacuated from coastal areas in Shanghai, Jiangsu, and Zhejiang. Transport was severely disrupted, with 600 flights into Shanghai canceled and ferries and rail services suspended. A person in Shandong was killed by a fallen tree.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A person in Shandong was killed by a fallen tree.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Direct economic losses reached ¥1.63 billion (US$246 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The article describes a heatwave event that affected various countries in Europe from June to September 2022. The heatwave resulted in widespread droughts and caused a confirmed death toll of 24,501, with upper estimates suggesting more than 61,000 heat-related deaths. The highest temperature recorded was 47.0°C (116.6°F) in Pinhão, Portugal, on 14 July. The heatwaves were part of climate change in Europe and were linked to the impact of climate change by climatologists.
Time_with_Annotation: From June to August 2022, persistent heatwaves affected parts of Europe, causing evacuations and a confirmed death toll of 24,501. These heat waves were the deadliest meteorological events in 2022.

Country_with_Annotation.Andorra: On 15 June, Andorra's weather agency, the National Meteorological Service of Andorra, issued a ... in the nation's capital, Andorra la Vella, temperatures were recorded to be over 36°C (97°F), far higher than the average for the time of year.
Country_with_Annotation.Austria: On 30 June, a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F) was recorded in Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, this was also Austria's heat record for June.
Country_with_Annotation.Belgium: On 19 July, the temperature reached 38.1°C (100.6°F) in Uccle, with the highest temperature that day being 40.0°C (104.0°F) in Kapelle-op-den-Bos.
Country_with_Annotation.Croatia: The heat dome which caused extreme temperatures in north-west Europe was expected to affect Croatia from 21 to 24 July. Temperatures peaked on 23 July, reaching 38-39°C (100-102°F) in cities including Zagreb, Osijek, Karlovac, Slavonski Brod, Knin.
Country_with_Annotation.Denmark: On 20 July, it reached 35.9°C (96.6°C) in Abed, Stokkemarke Parish, Lolland Municipality, breaking the all-time temperature record for that month.
Country_with_Annotation.Finland: Finland was hit by the heatwaves in late June and early July. The highest temperature of 32.5°C (90.5°C) was measured on 29 June in Utsjoki.
Country_with_Annotation.France: From 14 to 20 June, Germany saw 1,636 probable heat-related deaths attributed to temperatures reaching 39.2°C (102.6°C).
Country_with_Annotation.Germany: From 11 to 17 July, Germany saw an all-deaths excess death rate of 16% followed by 23% in the week from 18 to 24 July.
Country_with_Annotation.Greece: From mid-June to mid-August, Greece experienced one of its biggest heatwaves. A temperature of 42.1°C (107.8°C) was recorded on 23 June in Fthiotida.
Country_with_Annotation.Hungary: On 22 July, a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°C) was reported at Ãšjpest in Budapest, which broke the maximum temperature record for that day in the city.
Country_with_Annotation.Ireland: On 18 July, a temperature of 33.2°C (91.8°C) was reported at Allenwood one of the highest temperatures ever recorded in Ireland, breaking the Irish temperature record for July.
Country_with_Annotation.Italy: In Italy, the number of wildfires was three times the historical average by the end of June.
Country_with_Annotation.Luxembourg: On 19 July, it reached 36.3°C (97.3°C) in Luxembourg City. And 40.1°C (104.2°C) in Esch-sur-Alzette.
Country_with_Annotation.Malta: June was record warm for Malta, and the temperature reached a record high for June with 39.0°C (102.2°C) on 28 June.
Country_with_Annotation.Netherlands: On 18 July, the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute issued a code orange heat warning for the central and southern provinces, with forecasted temperatures of 36°C (97°F) in central provinces and 38-39°C (100-102°F) in the south on 19 July.
Country_with_Annotation.Norway: On 28 June, TromsÃ¸ reached 29.7°C (85.5°C) and Saltdal reached 31.6°C (88.9°C), both records for June.
Country_with_Annotation.Poland: On 19 June, temperatures in western Poland exceeded 36°C (97°F). In SÅ‚ubice, the highest temperature was 38.3°C (100.9°F), which equals the record for highest June temperature (set in 2019).
Country_with_Annotation.Portugal: According to Instituto Português do Mar e da Atmosfera (IPMA), the heatwave was the longest and had the greatest area extension of any July heatwave in Portugal since 1941.
Country_with_Annotation.San Marino: In late July, San Marino experienced a heatwave. On 24 July the temperature reached 39.6°C (103.3°F) in Dogana.

Country_with_Annotation.Slovakia: On 29 June, several stations reported a temperature of 37°C (99°F).
Country_with_Annotation.Slovenia: On 28 June, the Slovenian Environment Agency (ARSO) recorded a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F) in Podnanos.
Country_with_Annotation.Spain: On 12 June, temperatures reached 43.2°C (109.8°F) in Almadén (Ciudad Real), the highest value on the official start day of the heatwave.
Country_with_Annotation.Switzerland: On 15 June, a heat-wave alert was activated in the canton of Ticino.
Country_with_Annotation.United Kingdom: On 14 June, in view of the Met Office's forecast of high temperatures, the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) issued level 2 'alert and readiness' alerts in several regions for the period between midnight on 16 June and midnight on 18 June.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: These heat waves were the deadliest meteorological events in 2022. The highest temperature recorded was 47.0°C (116.6°F) in Pinhão, Portugal, on 14 July. Eurostat reported that the European Union saw 53,000 excess deaths in July, some of which may have occurred because of the heat wave.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: According to the Portuguese Health Ministry, the heatwave killed 1,063 people between 7 and 18 July.
Estimates from the Carlos III Health Institute placed the total June death toll at 830.
Final estimates from the Carlos III Health Institute placed the total July death toll at 2,063. However, in a report published later in the year, the July death toll was placed at 2,223.
In total, an estimated 18,010 excess deaths were reported due to the heat wave.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Sepat, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Egay, was the eighth named tropical storm and the strongest tropical cyclone of the 2007 Pacific typhoon season. It originated on August 11 via a low-circulation center SE of Naha, Okinawa, and was named by the Japan Meteorological Agency as Sepat on August 12 and Egay in the Philippines by PAGASA as it entered the PAR. Sepat underwent an explosive intensification on the night of August 13, reaching peak intensity at Category 5-equivalent super typhoon intensity the following morning. The storm maintained its strength for 2 days, until it underwent an eyewall replacement cycle, just before he storm makes landfall in Taiwan on August 17 (+21:00 UTC) as a Category 3-equivalent typhoon. After crossing the Taiwanese strait, Sepat; already weakening into Category 1 status due to unfavorable conditions, made a second landfall in China on August 18, 2007. The storm persisted across Mainland China, as it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on August 20, and Sepat, now an extratropical low continued through the Chinese mainland until it finally dissipated near Yunnan Province on August 24.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Typhoon Sepat, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Egay, was the eighth named tropical storm and the strongest tropical cyclone of the 2007 Pacific typhoon season, that affected the Philippines and made landfall in Taiwan and Fujian.
Sepat made landfall in eastern Taiwan between Taitung and Hualien on the morning of August 18 local time at around 5 a.m. (2100 UTC August 17) and weakened to a minimal typhoon.
After crossing the Taiwanese strait, Sepat; already weakening into Category 1 status due to unfavorable conditions, made a second landfall in China on August 18, 2007.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: More than 43 deaths were directly blamed on Sepat; 3 out of the 43 were from the Philippines due to drowning brought on by heavy rains from the southwest monsoon enhanced by Sepat

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Manzanita Fire was a wildfire that burned south of the towns of Beaumont and Banning near Highway 79 in Riverside County, California during June 2017. The fire had consumed some 6,309 acres (2553 ha) and was burning eastward towards the community of Poppet Flats and Highway 243... Fanned by Red Flag conditions, the Manzanita fire ignited from a traffic collision that grew to over 1,200 acres (490 ha) within several hours of burning... Overnight, the fire advanced toward the Silver Fire burn area of August 2013 where it would later burn itself out.

Time_with_Annotation.source: The fire was initially reported at 3:10 pm on Monday, June 26, off of Highway 79 in the Lamb Canyon area, ... The Manzanita fire was declared 100 percent contained at 6,309 acres (26 km2) in size.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Winter storm Christian, also known as St. Jude in the UK, Simone in Sweden, and Oktoberstormen in Denmark, battered northern Europe between October 27 and 29, affecting countries bordering the English Channel, North Sea, and Baltic Sea. It was one of the strongest storms of the last few years and reached peak wind gusts of more than 190 km/h (119mph) with storm surges reaching as high as 7.5 metres. Christian first impacted the south of Great Britain early on Monday, October 28, then moved along the English Channel and across Denmark and reached north-western Russia on Tuesday, though significantly weakened.
Time_with_Annotation: Winter storm Christian (known as ‘St. Jude’ in the United Kingdom) battered northern Europe between October 27 and 29...

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Blizzard of 1966 was a nor'easter that impacted the northeastern United States and Eastern Canada from January 29-February 1, 1966. Heavy lake effect snows preceded the cyclonic storm southeast of Lake Ontario.
Time_with_Annotation: The Blizzard of 1966 was a nor'easter that impacted the northeastern United States and Eastern Canada from January 29-February 1, 1966. Heavy lake effect snows preceded the cyclonic storm southeast of Lake Ontario. In and around the Lake Ontario snow belt, the storm period is considered to have lasted from January 27 - February 1, 1966, and the blizzard was a combination nor' easter and lake effect event in this region.

Country_with_Annotation.United States: Heavy lake effect snow fell southeast of Lake Ontario on January 27, 28, and 29, before the heavy snows from the cyclone reached the area on January 30... Winds were more than 60 miles per hour (97 km/h) during the storm... A total of 102 inches (260 cm) of snow was recorded at Southwest Oswego... The official Oswego snowfall total for the storm, measured by the cooperative observer at the State University College at Oswego was 68".
Country_with_Annotation.Canada: The Blizzard of 1966 was a nor'easter that impacted the northeastern United States and Eastern Canada from January 29-February 1, 1966... Heavy lake effect snows preceded the cyclonic storm southeast of Lake Ontario... Lake effect bands continued to impact northern Cayuga, Onondaga, Madison, Oswego, and Oneida counties even during the cyclonic portion of the event on January 30-31.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Within days, at least 142 people had been killed — 31 had frozen to death, 46 died in fires that started while people were trying to heat their home. Others died from heart attacks while shoveling snow or pushing cars, or traffic accidents caused by slick roads. The death toll reached 201 by Wednesday, February 2, as the storm eased.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Northeastern United States and Eastern Canada
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The Blizzard of 1966 was a nor'easter that impacted the northeastern United States and Eastern Canada from January 29-February 1, 1966. Heavy lake effect snows preceded the cyclonic storm southeast of Lake Ontario. Within days, at least 142 people had been killed.

Prior to the event, temperatures plunged to record low levels in central and northern New York as Arctic air dominated in the wake of an earlier cyclone. Syracuse, NY, tied its official record low of -26°F on January 26.

In and around the Lake Ontario snow belt, the storm period is considered to have lasted from January 27 - February 1, 1966, and the blizzard was a combination nor' easter and lake effect event in this region.

On Monday, January 31, federal government employees in Washington were excused from reporting to work and international airports were closed from Boston to Washington, D.C. The additional accumulation raised the snow level to 13 inches (33 cm) in Norfolk, Virginia.
New Market, Alabama, recorded a state record low of -27°F on January 30.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Olive was an erratic and slightly long-lived tropical cyclone that impacted Japan and affected Manchuria during early-August 1971. It severely disrupted the 13th World Scout Jamboree, which was being held in Fujinomiya, Shizuoka Prefecture. The system was first noted as an area of circulation in a near-equatorial trough, located to the east of Guam on July 24... The China Meteorological Agency started to monitor an area of scattered convection and circulation in weather maps which was located in a near-equatorial trough, located to the east of Guam... Nearly two days after, the agency upgraded the system to a weak tropical depression... On July 29, at 08:00 UTC, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated that the disturbance was now detected in their radar imagery and also started to watch the system's movement... At that time, the disturbance is highly disorganized, with its convection steered to the northeast... It started to move to the west while slowly consolidating before curving to the northeast... Between 11:00 and 12:00 UTC of that day, the JTWC upgraded the system to a tropical storm and named it Olive... The system had a good outflow, as being evidenced by radar imagery... Olive then slightly moved to the west-northwest before taking a north-northwestward track... The system then accelerated to the northwest before intensifying further to a Category 2 typhoon... It then started to slow down and impact the northern part of the Ryukyu Islands... with Olive passing near Yakushima Island before midnight at its peak... With the influence of a long-wave trough near the coast of East China, the system took a northward motion before making landfall on the main Japanese island of Kyushu... It rapidly unraveled to a tropical storm as it passed through Saga Prefecture before moving through the Sea of Japan... The extratropical remnants of Olive then passed through the La Pérouse Strait... before dissipating on August 10 near the International Date Line.
Time_with_Annotation: At 06:00 UTC on July 24, the China Meteorological Agency started to monitor an area of scattered convection and circulation in weather maps which was located in a near-equatorial trough, located to the east of Guam. ... The extratropical remnants of Olive then passed through the La Pérouse Strait, a strait which separates the Russian island of Sakhalin and northern part of Hokkaido in Japan before moving through the Pacific Ocean before dissipating on August 10 near the International Date Line.

Slow but gradual intensification occurred, becoming a tropical storm in the early hours of July 31 as it moved to the west, before taking a north-northwest track as it intensified to a typhoon on August 2 while approaching the Ryukyu Islands.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 90 deaths were attributed from Olive, with the majority in Japan. The system also caused widespread flooding and landslides through the country and nearby South Korea. The total damages are unknown.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Heavy inundation damages were also seen throughout the southern part of Japan. The Yakushima Station in Yakushima Island reported winds up to 80 knots and a minimum pressure of 938.7 mb, while no reports of damages were seen. In Kasedashi City, Kagoshima, torrential downpours broke the embankment of the Kaseda River, flooding houses and establishments near the area. The Kuma River in Kumamoto Prefecture also overflowed, destroying 209 houses and flooding 2,647 more. The dam in the prefecture, namely Ichifusa Dam, also released large amounts of water to avoid failure, flooding its lake and destroying some houses nearby. Total deaths from Olive in Japan were at 69, while the damages were unknown.

Despite not making landfall at any part of South Korea, Olive caused damages on the southern coasts of the country. Reports from different institutions and agencies, including Seoul's National Disaster Relief Center, said that Olive killed 27 in the country, all due to unknown reasons. Flash floods and widespread landslides were also seen.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Storm Kompasu, known in the Philippines as Severe Tropical Storm Maring[1] was a very large and deadly tropical cyclone that affected the Philippines, Taiwan, and southeast China. Part of the 2021 Pacific typhoon season, Kompasu originated from an area of low pressure east of the Philippines on 6 October 2021. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression that day. A day later, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration  (PAGASA) classified it as a tropical depression, naming it Maring. The cyclone was initially heavily disorganised, competing with another vortex, Tropical Depression Nando. Eventually, Maring became dominant, and the JMA reclassified it as a tropical storm, naming it Kompasu.

Time_with_Annotation.Start_Date: 'At 18:00 UTC (Coordinated Universal Time) on 6 October 2021, the JMA noted that an area of low pressure embedded within a large monsoonal circulation had formed to the north of Palau.'
Time_with_Annotation.End_Date: 'The JMA issued its final warning after downgrading it to a tropical depression at 18:00 UTC on 14 October.'

The cyclone dissipated on 14 October 2021 while located over Vietnam... On 13 October 2021, heavy rains affected Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, and Hainan provinces.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Cyclone Hollanda formed on 6 February 1994, in the central Indian Ocean in the Southern Hemisphere and moved southwestward for much of its duration. It intensified into a tropical cyclone on 9 February and struck the northern coast of Mauritius at 1800 UTC on 10 February at peak intensity, with winds of 155 km/h (95 mph) (10-minute sustained winds) as assessed by MFR. The JTWC estimated peak winds of 195 km/h (120 mph) (1-minute sustained winds). Hollanda maintained much of its intensity as it passed just southeast of Réunion early on 11 February and became extratropical on 14 February in the southern Indian Ocean.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: 6 February 1994 (1994-02-06)
Dissipated: 15 February 1994 (1994-02-15)

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Tropical Cyclone Hollanda was the worst tropical cyclone in Mauritius in 19 years. It formed on 6 February 1994, in the central Indian Ocean in the Southern Hemisphere. The cyclone moved southwestward for much of its duration, striking Mauritius on 10 February at peak intensity with winds of 218 km/h (135 mph). It later passed just southeast of Réunion before turning to the south and weakening. The cyclone became extratropical on 14 February in the southern Indian Ocean.

After becoming a tropical cyclone, Hollanda developed a small 20 km (12 mi) eye as it tracked toward the island of Mauritius, located east of Madagascar. Continuing to intensify, the cyclone struck the northern coast of the island at 1800 UTC on 10 February at peak intensity, with winds of 155 km/h (95 mph) (10-minute sustained winds) as assessed by MFR. In addition, the cyclone produced gusts to 230 km/h (140 mph). At the same time, the JTWC estimated peak winds of 195 km/h (120 mph) (1 minute sustained winds). While moving over Mauritius, the eye became disrupted, although Hollanda maintained much of its intensity as it passed just southeast of Réunion early on 11 February. The cyclone remained well-defined as it moved more poleward, and an irregular eye remained visible on satellite imagery.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Hollanda killed 2 people and caused $135 million in damage on Mauritius.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hollanda killed two people, and left $135 million in damage (1994 USD); the total included lost productivity, such as decreased sugar output.

Ignition of the phase-1 burn was scheduled for May 4, 2000. ... Over 400 families in the town of Los Alamos, New Mexico, lost their homes in the resulting 43,000-acre (170 km2) fire. ... Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Between 25–28 September 2019, Pune, India, and its division received a heavy amount of rainfall which caused flash flooding. In addition to people lost to these floods, other rain-related incidents such as collapsed compound walls of buildings have killed at least 21 people. More than 16 centimeters (6.3 in) of rain was measured in Pune, Baramati and Pune district between the night of 25 September and the afternoon of 26 September which was the highest rainfall in last 10 years. Coupled with the existing rain from the previous months, flash floods started to occur. The flash flooding was caused by short intense periods of rainfall that overwhelmed water runoff systems like nullahs and flooded roads.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A significant outbreak of tornadoes and severe convective weather struck a number of southern U.S. states last night and into this morning, with widespread damage experienced and deaths expected to run to between 50 and 100. The tornadoes and outbreak of severe thunderstorms was driven by weather patterns that resulted in numerous severe weather warnings and ultimately saw tornado emergencies raised for a wide swath of the U.S., across Arkansas, Missouri, Tennessee and Kentucky. In fact, the storm activity from Friday night into Saturday morning is being termed particularly severe for December, while one long-tracked tornado is thought to have crossed all four of the states mentioned, with damage experienced across a significant footprint as a result. That would be the first quad-state tornado in history and some reports suggest the track may break records, running for more than 210 miles and as much as 4 hours on the ground, while the tornado warning for this particular super cell system ran for over 7 hours, travelling from Arkansas almost into Ohio.
Time_with_Annotation: As of 9:30 PM CT (Dec. 10), low-level rotation showed incredibly intense tornadic activity having tracked across parts of FOUR states — AR, MO, TN, KY. This 'Quad-State' event has resulted in extensive damage, and sadly, loss of life. (Steve Bowen, Dec 11, 2021)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Julia was the easternmost Category 4 hurricane recorded in the Atlantic basin since reliable satellite observations became available. The twelfth tropical cyclone, fifth hurricane and fourth major hurricane of the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season, Julia rapidly developed on September 12 from a tropical wave near Cape Verde. Passing near the islands, the system quickly organized into Tropical Storm Julia the next day. On September 14, Julia attained hurricane status and subsequently entered a trend of rapid intensification; the storm strengthened from a minimal hurricane to a low-end Category 4 in only 24 hours.
Time_with_Annotation: The origins of Julia trace back to a vigorous tropical wave, or an equatorward low-pressure area, which emerged into the Atlantic along the western coast of Africa on September 11... By September 12, a tropical depression developed... The NHC initiated advisories at 1500 UTC that day... continuing generally eastward before executing an elongated loop to the south... Following this erratic track, the remnants of Hurricane Julia proceeded northwestward and came within 350 mi (560 km) of Bermuda, where they were once again briefly monitored by the NHC. However, chance of redevelopment dwindled... the NHC discontinued monitoring the system on September 28.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: No direct or indirect deaths were reported in the article.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Herwart was a European windstorm that affected Southern Denmark, Germany, Poland, Austria, Hungary and the Czech Republic on 28–29 October 2017. It was named by the Free University of Berlin Meteorology Department and formed as a secondary low to a more northerly centre of low pressure named Grischa coming southward from the Svalbard Islands region, the latter splitting in two low-pressure areas late on 28 October. The center of Herwart started rotating counterclockwise around the main low pressure area, passing over Norway, Sweden, Latvia and then losing power while moving over western Russia. In Denmark, which was hit on 28 October, the storm was named Ingolf. In Hungary, the storm was named Nárcisz (Narcissus), a Hungarian female name whose name day is on 29 October.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Phanfone, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ursula, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone which traversed the Philippines on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in 2019... The origins of Phanfone can be traced to an upper-level low which had formed near the Caroline Islands and gradually organized into a tropical depression on December 19... Phanfone, which is a Laotian word for Animal. The twenty-ninth and final named storm of the 2019 Pacific typhoon season, the origins of Phanfone can be traced to an upper-level low which had formed near the Caroline Islands and gradually organized into a tropical depression on December 19... Moving generally west-northwestward, the system intensified into a tropical storm on December 22 and moved into the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on the following day as it continued gaining strength... Phanfone intensified to typhoon status shortly before making its first landfall over the Eastern Visayas region on Christmas Eve... Phanfone maintained its typhoon strength for several hours as it exited the Philippines landmass before unfavorable conditions caused it to rapidly deteriorate and dissipate over the South China Sea.
Time_with_Annotation: Formed: December 19, 2019; Dissipated: December 29, 2019

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Prior to its formation on December 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) began monitoring a low pressure system to the southeast of Micronesia.

Phanfone, which is a Laotian word for Animal. The twenty-ninth and final named storm of the 2019 Pacific typhoon season, the origins of Phanfone can be traced to an upper-level low which had formed near the Caroline Islands and gradually organized into a tropical depression on December 19.

Moving generally west-northwestward, the system intensified into a tropical storm on December 22 and moved into the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on the following day as it continued gaining strength.
Phanfone intensified to typhoon status shortly before making its first landfall over the Eastern Visayas region on Christmas Eve.
Phanfone maintained its typhoon strength for several hours as it exited the Philippines landmass before rapidly deteriorating and dissipating over the South China Sea.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The formation of a tropical cyclone began near Palau on October 24, which was designated 30W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC). It was named 'Reming' by PAGASA and later named 'Xangsane'. Xangsane made landfall in southern Luzon in the Philippines on October 27 and turned north-northeastward over the South China Sea. On October 29, Xangsane reached its peak intensity with 10-minute sustained winds of 140 km/h (87 mph), 1-minute sustained winds of 165 km/h (103 mph), and a minimum barometric pressure of 960 hPa (28 inHg). The storm paralleled the eastern coast of Taiwan the next day and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the East China Sea on November 1.
